title: How to Convert XML to JSON: Transform Legacy Data for Modern Applications
content:
## Introduction

XML was the standard for data exchange before JSON became dominant. Converting XML to JSON modernizes your data for use in contemporary web applications, APIs, and JavaScript-based systems. Our free XML to JSON converter handles attributes, namespaces, and complex nested structures.

## Key Takeaways

- Convert XML documents to JSON instantly
- Handle attributes with @ prefix notation
- Support for namespaces and CDATA
- Preserve structure and hierarchy
- Pretty-printed or minified output

## What is XML to JSON Conversion?

XML to JSON conversion transforms XML's element-based structure into JSON's object-based format:

**XML Input:**
```xml
<user id="123">
  <name>John</name>
  <email>john@test.com</email>
</user>
```

**JSON Output:**
```json
{
  "user": {
    "@id": "123",
    "name": "John",
    "email": "john@test.com"
  }
}
```

## Why Convert XML to JSON?

### 1. Modern Web Development

JSON is the web standard:
- Native JavaScript support
- Smaller payload size
- Easier parsing
- Better tooling

### 2. API Modernization

Update legacy APIs:
- SOAP to REST migration
- Modernize integrations
- Improve performance
- Simplify clients

### 3. Data Integration

Connect disparate systems:
- Legacy system output
- Modern application input
- Cross-platform data
- System migrations

### 4. Mobile Development

JSON works better on mobile:
- Smaller downloads
- Faster parsing
- Lower memory
- Native support

### Step 2: Configure Options

- @ prefix (default: @id)
- Separate attributes object

**Text Content:**
- #text key for mixed content

**Array Detection:**
- Repeated elements as arrays
- Always arrays option

### Step 3: Convert

Click Convert to transform. Preview the JSON structure.

### Step 4: Download

## Features and Capabilities

### Element Handling

| XML Feature | JSON Output |
|-------------|-------------|
| Elements | Object keys |
| Attributes | @-prefixed keys |
| Text content | String values |
| Nested elements | Nested objects |
| Repeated elements | Arrays |
| CDATA | Preserved text |

### Namespace Support

- Namespace prefixes preserved
- Optional namespace stripping
- Qualified name support
- Default namespace handling

### Special Cases

| XML | JSON Handling |
|-----|---------------|
| Empty elements | null or {} |
| Mixed content | #text key |
| Comments | Typically stripped |
| Processing instructions | Stripped |

## Best Practices and Tips

### Understanding Conversion Patterns

**Simple elements:**
```xml
<name>John</name>
```
```json
{"name": "John"}
```

**Elements with attributes:**
```xml
<user id="1">John</user>
```
```json
{"user": {"@id": "1", "#text": "John"}}
```

**Repeated elements:**
```xml
<items>
  <item>A</item>
  <item>B</item>
</items>
```
```json
{"items": {"item": ["A", "B"]}}
```

### Handling Complex Structures

| Pattern | Approach |
|---------|----------|
| Deep nesting | Convert directly, simplify after |
| Mixed content | Use #text for text nodes |
| Multiple roots | Wrap in container |
| Large documents | Process in chunks |

### Post-Conversion Cleanup

- Remove @-prefixes if not needed
- Flatten unnecessary nesting
- Convert types as needed
- Validate structure

## XML Structure Considerations

### Well-Formed XML

Converter requires valid XML:
- Proper opening/closing tags
- Quoted attributes
- Valid characters
- Single root element

### Document vs Fragment

**Full document:**
```xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<root>...</root>
```

**Fragment (also supported):**
```xml
<item>value</item>
```

### Encoding

- UTF-8 recommended
- Character entities decoded
- Special characters preserved
- Unicode supported

## Frequently Asked Questions

### How are XML attributes converted?

Attributes are converted to properties with an @ prefix. For example, `id="123"` becomes `"@id": "123"`. You can configure the prefix or handling method.

### What happens to namespaces?

Namespace prefixes are preserved in the output. You can optionally strip namespaces for cleaner JSON.

### How are repeated elements handled?

Repeated sibling elements with the same name are converted to arrays. Single elements remain as objects unless you configure always-array mode.

### Is CDATA preserved?

Yes, CDATA content is extracted and preserved as text in the JSON output.

### What about XML comments?

Comments are typically stripped during conversion as they have no JSON equivalent.

### Can I convert SOAP messages?

Yes, SOAP envelopes are converted like any XML. The envelope structure will be preserved in the JSON hierarchy.

## Conclusion

Converting XML to JSON modernizes your data for contemporary applications and APIs. Our free XML to JSON converter handles the complexity of attributes, namespaces, and nested structures while producing clean, usable JSON.
